awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: Development of Single-Stage Power Modules for Modular Medium-Voltage Electric Vehicle Fast Chargers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project is to provide an electric vehicle charger that is at least 10 times smaller than existing EV charging systems and wastes half as much power during the charging process. This advanced is based on the proposed solid-state transformer (SST) technology, which makes use of a high frequency magnetics to shrink the system size and improve efficiency. The SST connects directly to the medium voltage distribution system, eliminating bulky step-down transformers, and eliminating power conversion stages. A smaller, more efficient EV charger translates into cheaper system installation, higher revenue, and better site utilization for charging station owners, and cheaper and faster charging for the EV owners. The same technology can serve other applications where large DC loads are present, including the data centers, which already make up 1.8% of total US power consumption. 


The proposed project will advance technologies developed under the FREEDM ERC, by solving a number of important challenges in the area of medium voltage power conversion. We will prove that our recently discovered, provisional patent protected, single stage power converter can reduce system costs and improve system efficiency. The team will analytically derive the conditions that allow for switching device soft-switching transitions that result in minimal system losses. We will develop analytical models to determine the optimal switching trajectories that consider phase shift, switching frequency and non-linear saturable inductor elements as independent variables. With an analytical representation of the optimal modulation schemes for the proposed controller, the team will develop a design space exploration tool to systematically trade off converter design parameters against multiple performance criteria, namely cost, efficiency, power density and reliability.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The specific goals of this PFI-TT project is to develop further the solid state transformer (SST) technology so that it is reliable and cost-competitive with the state-of-the-art solutions. The two major activities relate to the development of the single stage topology for the medium voltage converter and the development of a design space exploration framework which will allow for the optimization of the converter to minimize costs and maximize reliability.

Intellectual Merit: First, we developed a novel single-stage topology which reduces component count while keeping the power factor correction (PFC) function, thus reducing cost and reducing the mean time between failures. Various aspects of this work were reported in two journal and two conference publications and one invention disclosure. Second, we developed a design space exploration tool to optimize any converter. By exploring a very large design space, the team can arrive at a design that meets the strict reliability criteria, while minimizing cost and optimizing efficiency. Our initial focus was on design space optimization of simple topologies (like buck and boost converters); our goal is to generalize the process to optimize any power electronics conversion system, but work remains in this effort. Currently the design space exploration tool is used in a new graduate course offered annually by the PI at NC State University.

Boarder Impact: The team has significantly expanded the visibility and understanding in the field of the benefits of SST technology, recognizing the electric vehicle fast charging offers a great first application of SSTs, where the benefits of the technology can provide financial and societal benefits. The team published an article in IEEE Electrification Magazine and IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification describing the documenting the benefits of employing SSTs to power the next generation of electric vehicle extreme fast chargers that connect directly to the medium voltage distribution line. The project also helped support a number of graduate students involved in the project, by providing training in power electronics design, control and optimization. These students are now a part of the highly sought-after workforce, with one graduate working at a National Laboratory and another working as a tenure track faculty.

Efforts to realize the commercialization potential of the funded technology: The team was able to secure two multi-million dollar grants from the Department of Energy Vehicle Technologies Office, to further develop and demonstrate medium voltage SSTs (DE-EE0008450: Intelligent, Grid-Friendly, 1 MW Medium Voltage Extreme Fast Charger; DE-EE0009871: Ultra-low Cost, All-SiC Modular Power Converters for DC Fast Charging Equipment Connected Directly to Medium Voltage Distribution System). This work will allow the team develop and deploy medium voltage equipment in the field, which is one of the major steps in commercializing the proposed technology. The team, led by the PI of this project, involves utilities and vendors as partners, who will help to commercialize this technology. These interactions will allow the team to test the assumptions about the product-market fit, and provides many opportunities for customer discovery and regulatory assessment. Further, this work demonstrates concrete efforts made by the team members to realize the full commercialization potential of the funded technology.

 


Last Modified: 03/27/2022
Modified by: Srdjan M Lukic
